p: Boswellia sacra syn. B. carteri is one of the most popular frankincense essential oils for both aromatherapeutic applications and in perfumes. The status of B. carteri as a separate species is questionable, typically being considered botanically as being part of a single, highly variable species, B. sacra [ 6]. However, the two show differences in morphology, growth form, resin chemistry, and geography; the Arabian populations are termed B. sacra while the African populations are termed B. carteri [ 1, 6, 7] (personal observations). Additionally, much of the scientific literature, including the phytochemical literature, refers to B. carteri as distinct from B. sacra, and it is recognized commercially as a separate entity [ 8, 9, 10, 11]. For these reasons, we here refer to the African populations of B. sacra syn. B. carteri simply as Boswellia carteri. Boswellia carteri is native to Somaliland and the Puntland state of Somalia. It grows on limestone and volcanic rock (as well as occasionally on soil) from sea level up to 1500 m in elevation [ 6, 12] (personal observations).
